leadingComments.value:
*
     * @desc
     *
     * @lineNumber
     * 90
     * @param
     * {undefined} videoSamples

trailingComments.value: If we're remuxing audio and video progressively, wait until we've received enough samples for each track before proceeding.
This is done to synchronize the audio and video streams. We know if the current segment will have samples if the "pid"
parameter is greater than -1. The pid is set when the PMT is parsed, which contains the tracks list.
However, if the initSegment has already been generated, or we've reached the end of a segment (flush),
then we can remux one track without waiting for the other.

leadingComments.value: If we're remuxing audio and video progressively, wait until we've received enough samples for each track before proceeding.
This is done to synchronize the audio and video streams. We know if the current segment will have samples if the "pid"
parameter is greater than -1. The pid is set when the PMT is parsed, which contains the tracks list.
However, if the initSegment has already been generated, or we've reached the end of a segment (flush),
then we can remux one track without waiting for the other.

value.raw: video samples due to a missing keyframe
value.cooked: video samples due to a missing keyframe

leadingComments.value: timeOffset is expected to be the offset of the first timestamp of this fragment (first DTS)
if first audio DTS is not aligned with first video DTS then we need to take that into account
when providing timeOffset to remuxAudio / remuxVideo. if we don't do that, there might be a permanent / small
drift between audio and video streams

trailingComments.value: Purposefully remuxing audio before video, so that remuxVideo can use nextAudioPts, which is calculated in remuxAudio.

leadingComments.value: if initSegment was generated without audio samples, regenerate it again

trailingComments.value: if initSegment was generated without video samples, regenerate it again

leadingComments.value: if initSegment was generated without video samples, regenerate it again
Purposefully remuxing audio before video, so that remuxVideo can use nextAudioPts, which is calculated in remuxAudio.

let's use audio sampling rate as MP4 time scale.
rationale is that there is a integer nb of audio frames per audio sample (1024 for AAC)
using audio sampling rate here helps having an integer MP4 frame duration
this avoids potential rounding issue and AV sync issue
Chrome and Safari
Firefox

we use input time scale straight away to avoid rounding issues on frame duration / cts computation

In some cases, a segment's audio track duration may exceed the video track duration.
Since we've already remuxed audio, and we know how long the audio track is, we look to
see if the delta to the next segment is longer than maxBufferHole.
If so, playback would potentially get stuck, so we artificially inflate
the duration of the last frame to minimize any potential gap between segments.
We subtract lastFrameDuration from deltaToFrameEnd to try to prevent any video
frame overlap. maxBufferHole should be >> lastFrameDuration anyway.

trailingComments.value: for audio samples, also consider consecutive fragments as being contiguous (even if a level switch occurs),
- less than 100ms gaps between new time offset (if accurate) and next expected PTS OR
contiguous fragments are consecutive fragments from same quality level (same level, new SN = old SN + 1)
and this also avoids audio glitches/cut when switching quality, or reporting wrong duration on first audio frame

leadingComments.value: window.audioSamples ? window.audioSamples.push(inputSamples.map(s => s.pts)) : (window.audioSamples = [inputSamples.map(s => s.pts)]);
for audio samples, also consider consecutive fragments as being contiguous (even if a level switch occurs),
for sake of clarity:
consecutive fragments are frags with
- less than 100ms gaps between new time offset (if accurate) and next expected PTS OR
- less than 20 audio frames distance
contiguous fragments are consecutive fragments from same quality level (same level, new SN = old SN + 1)
this helps ensuring audio continuity
and this also avoids audio glitches/cut when switching quality, or reporting wrong duration on first audio frame
compute normalized PTS

trailingComments.value: in case all samples have negative PTS, and have been filtered out, return now

leadingComments.value: filter out sample with negative PTS that are not playable anyway
if we don't remove these negative samples, they will shift all audio samples forward.
leading to audio overlap between current / next fragment
in case all samples have negative PTS, and have been filtered out, return now
Set the start to 0 to match video so that start gaps larger than inputSampleDuration are filled with silence
When not seeking, not live, and LevelDetails.PTSKnown, use fragment start as predicted next audio PTS
if frags are not contiguous and if we cant trust time offset, let's use first sample PTS as next audio PTS

trailingComments.value: If the audio track is missing samples, the frames seem to get "left-shifted" within the
resulting mp4 segment, causing sync issues and leaving gaps at the end of the audio segment.
In an effort to prevent this from happening, we inject frames here where there are gaps.
When possible, we inject a silent frame; when that's not possible, we duplicate the last

leadingComments.value: First, let's see how far off this frame is from where we expect it to be

trailingComments.value: When remuxing with video, if we're overlapping by more than a duration, drop this sample to stay in sync
1: We're more than maxAudioFramesDrift frame away
Adjust nextPts so that silent samples are aligned with media pts. This will prevent media samples from
later being shifted if nextPts is based on timeOffset and delta is not a multiple of inputSampleDuration.

leadingComments.value: Adjust nextPts so that silent samples are aligned with media pts. This will prevent media samples from

leadingComments.value: When remuxing with video, if we're overlapping by more than a duration, drop this sample to stay in sync
If the audio track is missing samples, the frames seem to get "left-shifted" within the
resulting mp4 segment, causing sync issues and leaving gaps at the end of the audio segment.
In an effort to prevent this from happening, we inject frames here where there are gaps.
When possible, we inject a silent frame; when that's not possible, we duplicate the last
frame.
If we have more than one sample, set the duration of the sample to the "real" duration; the PTS diff with
the previous sample

If we're remuxing audio and video progressively, wait until we've received enough samples for each track before proceeding.
This is done to synchronize the audio and video streams. We know if the current segment will have samples if the "pid"
parameter is greater than -1. The pid is set when the PMT is parsed, which contains the tracks list.
However, if the initSegment has already been generated, or we've reached the end of a segment (flush),
then we can remux one track without waiting for the other.
timeOffset is expected to be the offset of the first timestamp of this fragment (first DTS)
if first audio DTS is not aligned with first video DTS then we need to take that into account
when providing timeOffset to remuxAudio / remuxVideo. if we don't do that, there might be a permanent / small
drift between audio and video streams
Purposefully remuxing audio before video, so that remuxVideo can use nextAudioPts, which is calculated in remuxAudio.
if initSegment was generated without audio samples, regenerate it again
if initSegment was generated without video samples, regenerate it again
Allow ID3 and text to remux, even if more audio/video samples are required

this avoids potential rounding issue and AV sync issue

Firefox

In some cases, a segment's audio track duration may exceed the video track duration.
Since we've already remuxed audio, and we know how long the audio track is, we look to
see if the delta to the next segment is longer than maxBufferHole.
If so, playback would potentially get stuck, so we artificially inflate
the duration of the last frame to minimize any potential gap between segments.
We subtract lastFrameDuration from deltaToFrameEnd to try to prevent any video
frame overlap. maxBufferHole should be >> lastFrameDuration anyway.
Chrome workaround, mark first sample as being a Random Access Point (keyframe) to avoid sourcebuffer append issue
https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=229412
Fix for "CNN special report, with CC" in test-streams (Safari browser only)
Ignore DTS when frame durations are irregular. Safari MSE does not handle this leading to gaps.
next AVC sample DTS should be equal to last sample DTS + last sample duration (in PES timescale)

window.audioSamples ? window.audioSamples.push(inputSamples.map(s => s.pts)) : (window.audioSamples = [inputSamples.map(s => s.pts)]);
for audio samples, also consider consecutive fragments as being contiguous (even if a level switch occurs),
for sake of clarity:
consecutive fragments are frags with
- less than 100ms gaps between new time offset (if accurate) and next expected PTS OR
- less than 20 audio frames distance
contiguous fragments are consecutive fragments from same quality level (same level, new SN = old SN + 1)
this helps ensuring audio continuity
and this also avoids audio glitches/cut when switching quality, or reporting wrong duration on first audio frame
compute normalized PTS
filter out sample with negative PTS that are not playable anyway
if we don't remove these negative samples, they will shift all audio samples forward.
leading to audio overlap between current / next fragment
in case all samples have negative PTS, and have been filtered out, return now
Set the start to 0 to match video so that start gaps larger than inputSampleDuration are filled with silence
When not seeking, not live, and LevelDetails.PTSKnown, use fragment start as predicted next audio PTS
if frags are not contiguous and if we cant trust time offset, let's use first sample PTS as next audio PTS
If the audio track is missing samples, the frames seem to get "left-shifted" within the
resulting mp4 segment, causing sync issues and leaving gaps at the end of the audio segment.
In an effort to prevent this from happening, we inject frames here where there are gaps.
When possible, we inject a silent frame; when that's not possible, we duplicate the last
frame.
First, let's see how far off this frame is from where we expect it to be
When remuxing with video, if we're overlapping by more than a duration, drop this sample to stay in sync
eslint-disable-line brace-style
Insert missing frames if:
1: We're more than maxAudioFramesDrift frame away
2: Not more than MAX_SILENT_FRAME_DURATION away
3: currentTime (aka nextPtsNorm) is not 0
4: remuxing with video (videoTimeOffset !== undefined)
Adjust nextPts so that silent samples are aligned with media pts. This will prevent media samples from
later being shifted if nextPts is based on timeOffset and delta is not a multiple of inputSampleDuration.
If we have more than one sample, set the duration of the sample to the "real" duration; the PTS diff with
the previous sample
set PTS/DTS to expected PTS/DTS
remember first PTS of our audioSamples

concatenate the audio data and construct the mdat in place
                      (need 8 more bytes to fill length and mdat type)
no audio samples
Default the sample's duration to the computed mp4SampleDuration, which will either be 1024 for AAC or 1152 for MPEG
In the case that we have 1 sample, this will be the duration. If we have more than one sample, the duration
becomes the PTS diff with the previous sample
We could end up with no audio samples if all input samples were overlapping with the previously remuxed ones
The next audio sample PTS should be equal to last sample PTS + duration
Set the track samples from inputSamples to outputSamples before remuxing
Clear the track samples. This also clears the samples array in the demuxer, since the reference is shared

PTS is 33bit (from 0 to 2^33 -1)

      PTS looping occured. fill the gap
